awd_titl_txt: RUI: Boronic Ester Modified Polysaccharides for Oxidation-Responsive Delivery Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical summary:

The field of drug delivery aims to improve or control how bioactive molecules get to their intended target. This is most often accomplished using carrier "vehicles" that are designed to locally release their payload at a desired time, rate, and location, often in response to a specific signal molecule. Hydrogen peroxide is an oxidizing agent that is frequently used as this signal molecule because it is generated as a part of the immune response and in ischemic events like heart attacks and strokes. Boronic esters are chemical groups used to give materials sensitivity to hydrogen peroxide; this research investigates the effects of making changes to the molecular structure surrounding these boronic esters. The PI synthesizes new materials by modifying biologically derived polymers with a range of boronic esters, and then we measure whether and how those modifications lead to materials capable of carrying payload molecules and releasing them in response to oxidizing environments. This research aims to discover design parameters that might be used to make the next generation of drug delivery vehicles. Mount Holyoke College is the oldest women's college in the US, and serves a diverse student body. The students who engage in this research will learn modern laboratory techniques and scientific communication skills, and their experiences will prepare them for future endeavors in a wide variety of fields.

Technical summary:

The use of arylboronic esters to endow molecular sensors and delivery vehicles with sensitivity to hydrogen peroxides has become widespread in the past 15 years. The large majority of these contain pinacol (2,3-dimethylbutane-2,3-diol) as the esterifying group. The identity of this diol influences the rate of degradation in response to hydrogen peroxide, and may additionally affect the interactions between boronic esters and biomolecules. This project will explore the effects replacing this group with more rigid or sterically hindered diols in the context of modified polysaccharide-based polymeric materials. These materials will be evaluated based on their solution-processability, hydrolytic stability, and sensitivity to hydrogen peroxide. Additionally, esterifying diols will be modified with hydrophobicity-modulating groups or releasable bioactive molecules, and their ability to encapsulate and release molecular payloads will be evaluated. This research will result in improved understanding of the design parameters for boronic ester-containing molecules and materials. Mount Holyoke College is the oldest women?s college in the US, and serves a diverse student body. The students that engage in this research will learn modern laboratory techniques, scientific communication skills, and their experiences will prepare them for future endeavors in a wide variety of fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF MOUNT HOLYOKE COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
The field of drug delivery aims to direct the release and retention of therapeutic molecules in the body. An important area within the field drug delivery involves triggered release, where delivery is initiated by a chemical or physical signal. The oxidative molecule hydrogen peroxide is associated with damage after heart attack and stroke, as well as neurodegenerative disorders, and is an important component of the immune response. Because of this, it is an appealing target for triggered release drug delivery.

The most widely used molecular trigger for responsiveness to hydrogen peroxide is the arylboronic ester. Oxidation by hydrogen peroxide causes degradation of this molecular trigger and releases the payload molecule or material it was protecting. Historically, pinacol has been used as the diol cap on the boronic ester group. Work funded by this grant investigated the role of this diol group in controlling the peroxide-triggered release reaction as well as the material properties of drug delivery vehicles prepared using arylboronic ester triggering groups. It was found that the rigid plant-derived diols pinanediol and nopoldiol improve the stability of arylboronic esters toward undesired side reactions. Importantly, these groups with improved stability retained their responsiveness toward peroxide-triggered release. 


Characterization and quantification of these improved triggering groups may lay the groundwork for improved oxidation-sensing molecules and oxidation-responding materials. Although many of the materials generated through this work did not possess the properties needed to be effective materials for drug delivery vehicles, one material was identified that was able to form robust microparticulate delivery vehicles. These vehicles were found to be non-cytotoxic and to provide controlled extended release of the therapeutic small molecule resiquimod, demonstrating potential for use in immunotherapeutic applications.

The work supported by this grant was carried out through the training of the next generation of scientists. Seven undergraduate students were directly trained in the practice of organic molecule and materials synthesis, and were trained to plan and carry out scientific work. Students trained through this grant have gone on to become graduate researchers, research scientists, and a teacher. High school students were involved in this work through summer internships, and the training was instrumental in their decisions to pursue careers in medicine and science. Finally, this grant supported revitalization of in-person research at Mount Holyoke College after the COVID-19 lockdowns of 2020 and 2021 through support of a broad-audience introductory research experience for students who had missed foundational laboratory classes.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Kyle Broaders

Images (1 of )
  • Oxidation-responsive drug delivery vehicles are made by chemical modification of biocompatible biomaterials then formation into microparticles. Exposure to a molecular signal (hydrogen peroxide) triggers release of encapsulated cargo and regeneration of starting biomaterial.
    Kyle Broaders
    Public Domain
    Kyle Broaders
    Preparation of responsive drug delivery vehicles
  • Arylboronic esters oxidize when exposed to hydrogen peroxide, leading to regeneration of unmodified materials. Pinacol is the most commonly used diol in arylboronic esters; by replacing this diol, improved properties can be accessed.
    Kyle Broaders
    Public Domain
    Kyle Broaders
    Oxidation responsive molecular trigger
